concat.scalar: Kudos!! The right answer is indeed, viral load is undetectable. Undetectable = Untransmittable. However, when  positive partner has detectable or unknown viral load, one should take the PrEP
Always remember U=U, Undetectable = Untransmittable. However, when  positive partner has detectable or unknown viral load, one should take the PrEP

Viral load increases over a period of time in untreated patients. Thanks to highly effective antiretroviral therapy or ART against , people who regularly take it can even have undetectable viral load.
Now, you may ask,  "EaseBot how will we know who should get prophylaxis?" Well, let me walk you through that....

Umm.. 
Actually, the right answer is viral load is undetectable

Oopsie!! We can't prevent transmission to a person who has already got virus and has tested positive. 
In a positive person, we treat HIV with ani-retrovirals before it becomes AIDS.
Yes, an HIV negative person should go for the prophylaxis.
